qas.question: The fact that gases ability to conduct heat decreases with pressure is used by what form of measurement?
How is the wire filament in a Thermal conductivity gauge heated?
What is a Pirani gauge sensitive to?

answers.text: chemical composition of the gases being measured

qas.question: What is a RTD used for on a Thermal Conductivity gauge?

answers.text: to measure the temperature of the filament

qas.question: A Pirani gauge is accurate within what ranges?
How does plantinums ability to conduct heat decrease?
What kind of filament does the RTD use?

plausible_answers.text: both the heated element and RTD

qas.question: How do thermal conductivity gauges use a single platinum filament as?
How quickly does a filament lose heat?
Pressure is sensitive to the heated element of what?

context: <a0_0>Thermal conductivity gauges<a0_0/> rely on the fact that the ability of a gas to conduct heat decreases <b5_0>with pressure<b5_0/>. In this type of gauge, a wire filament is heated <a1_0>by running current through it<a1_0/>. A thermocouple or Resistance Temperature Detector (RTD) can then be used <a3_0>to measure the temperature of the filament<a3_0/>. This temperature is dependent on the rate at which the filament loses heat to the surrounding gas, and therefore on the thermal conductivity. A common variant is the Pirani gauge which uses <b6_0>a single platinum filament<b6_0/> as <b7_0>both the heated element and RTD<b7_0/>. These gauges are accurate <b8_0>from <a4_0>10 torr to 10−3 torr<b8_0/><a4_0/>, but they are sensitive to the <a2_0>chemical composition of <b9_0>the gases being measured<b9_0/><a2_0/>.
